3/*
4 * ntp_loopfilter.c - implements the NTP loop filter algorithm
5 *
6 * ATTENTION: Get approval from Dave Mills on all changes to this file!
7 *
8 */
9#ifdef HAVE_CONFIG_H
10# include <config.h>
11#endif

13#ifdef USE_SNPRINTB
14# include <util.h>
15#endif
16#include "ntpd.h"
17#include "ntp_io.h"
18#include "ntp_unixtime.h"
19#include "ntp_stdlib.h"

21#include <limits.h>

23#include <ctype.h>

25#include <signal.h>
26#include <setjmp.h>

28#ifdef KERNEL_PLL
29#include "ntp_syscall.h"

32/*
33 * This is an implementation of the clock discipline algorithm described
34 * in UDel TR 97-4-3, as amended. It operates as an adaptive parameter,
35 * hybrid phase/frequency-lock loop. A number of sanity checks are
36 * included to protect against timewarps, timespikes and general mayhem.
37 * All units are in s and s/s, unless noted otherwise.
38 */
39#define CLOCK_MAX .128 /* default step threshold (s) */
40#define CLOCK_MINSTEP 300. /* default stepout threshold (s) */
41#define CLOCK_PANIC 1000. /* default panic threshold (s) */
42#define CLOCK_PHI 15e-6 /* max frequency error (s/s) */
43#define CLOCK_PLL 16. /* PLL loop gain (log2) */
44#define CLOCK_AVG 8. /* parameter averaging constant */
45#define CLOCK_FLL .25 /* FLL loop gain */
46#define CLOCK_FLOOR .0005 /* startup offset floor (s) */
47#define CLOCK_ALLAN 11 /* Allan intercept (log2 s) */
48#define CLOCK_LIMIT 30 /* poll-adjust threshold */
49#define CLOCK_PGATE 4. /* poll-adjust gate */
50#define PPS_MAXAGE 120 /* kernel pps signal timeout (s) */
51#define FREQTOD(x) ((x) / 65536e6) /* NTP to double */
52#define DTOFREQ(x) ((int32)((x) * 65536e6)) /* double to NTP */
53
54/*
55 * Clock discipline state machine. This is used to control the
56 * synchronization behavior during initialization and following a
57 * timewarp.
58 *
59 * State < step > step Comments
60 * ========================================================
61 * NSET FREQ step, FREQ freq not set
62 *
63 * FSET SYNC step, SYNC freq set
64 *
65 * FREQ if (mu < 900) if (mu < 900) set freq direct
66 * ignore ignore
67 * else else
68 * freq, SYNC freq, step, SYNC
69 *
70 * SYNC SYNC SPIK, ignore adjust phase/freq
71 *
72 * SPIK SYNC if (mu < 900) adjust phase/freq
73 * ignore
74 * step, SYNC
75 */
76/*
77 * Kernel PLL/PPS state machine. This is used with the kernel PLL
78 * modifications described in the documentation.
79 *
80 * If kernel support for the ntp_adjtime() system call is available, the
81 * ntp_control flag is set. The ntp_enable and kern_enable flags can be
82 * set at configuration time or run time using ntpdc. If ntp_enable is
83 * false, the discipline loop is unlocked and no corrections of any kind
84 * are made. If both ntp_control and kern_enable are set, the kernel
85 * support is used as described above; if false, the kernel is bypassed
86 * entirely and the daemon discipline used instead.
87 *
88 * There have been three versions of the kernel discipline code. The
89 * first (microkernel) now in Solaris discipilnes the microseconds. The
90 * second and third (nanokernel) disciplines the clock in nanoseconds.
91 * These versions are identifed if the symbol STA_PLL is present in the
92 * header file /usr/include/sys/timex.h. The third and current version
93 * includes TAI offset and is identified by the symbol NTP_API with
94 * value 4.
95 *
96 * Each PPS time/frequency discipline can be enabled by the atom driver
97 * or another driver. If enabled, the STA_PPSTIME and STA_FREQ bits are
98 * set in the kernel status word; otherwise, these bits are cleared.
99 * These bits are also cleard if the kernel reports an error.
100 *
101 * If an external clock is present, the clock driver sets STA_CLK in the
102 * status word. When the local clock driver sees this bit, it updates
103 * via this routine, which then calls ntp_adjtime() with the STA_PLL bit
104 * set to zero, in which case the system clock is not adjusted. This is
105 * also a signal for the external clock driver to discipline the system
106 * clock. Unless specified otherwise, all times are in seconds.
107 */
108/*
109 * Program variables that can be tinkered.
110 */
111double clock_max_back = CLOCK_MAX; /* step threshold */
112double clock_max_fwd = CLOCK_MAX; /* step threshold */
113double clock_minstep = CLOCK_MINSTEP; /* stepout threshold */
114double clock_panic = CLOCK_PANIC; /* panic threshold */
115double clock_phi = CLOCK_PHI; /* dispersion rate (s/s) */
116u_char allan_xpt = CLOCK_ALLAN; /* Allan intercept (log2 s) */
117
118/*
119 * Program variables
120 */
121static double clock_offset; /* offset */
122double clock_jitter; /* offset jitter */
123double drift_comp; /* frequency (s/s) */
124static double init_drift_comp; /* initial frequency (PPM) */
125double clock_stability; /* frequency stability (wander) (s/s) */
126double clock_codec; /* audio codec frequency (samples/s) */
127static u_long clock_epoch; /* last update */
128u_int sys_tai; /* TAI offset from UTC */
129static int loop_started; /* TRUE after LOOP_DRIFTINIT */
130static void rstclock (int, double); /* transition function */
131static double direct_freq(double); /* direct set frequency */
132static void set_freq(double); /* set frequency */
133#ifndef PATH_MAX
134# define PATH_MAX MAX_PATH
135#endif
136static char relative_path[PATH_MAX + 1]; /* relative path per recursive make */
137static char *this_file = NULL;
138
139#ifdef KERNEL_PLL
140static struct timex ntv; /* ntp_adjtime() parameters */
141int pll_status; /* last kernel status bits */
142#if defined(STA_NANO) && NTP_API == 4
143static u_int loop_tai; /* last TAI offset */
144#endif /* STA_NANO */
145static void start_kern_loop(void);
146static void stop_kern_loop(void);
147#endif /* KERNEL_PLL */
148
149/*
150 * Clock state machine control flags
151 */
152int ntp_enable = TRUE; /* clock discipline enabled */
153int pll_control; /* kernel support available */
154int kern_enable = TRUE; /* kernel support enabled */
155int hardpps_enable; /* kernel PPS discipline enabled */
156int ext_enable; /* external clock enabled */
157int pps_stratum; /* pps stratum */
158int kernel_status; /* from ntp_adjtime */
159int force_step_once = FALSE; /* always step time once at startup (-G) */
160int mode_ntpdate = FALSE; /* exit on first clock set (-q) */
161int freq_cnt; /* initial frequency clamp */
162int freq_set; /* initial set frequency switch */
163
164/*
165 * Clock state machine variables
166 */
167int state = 0; /* clock discipline state */
168u_char sys_poll; /* time constant/poll (log2 s) */
169int tc_counter; /* jiggle counter */
170double last_offset; /* last offset (s) */
171
172/*
173 * Huff-n'-puff filter variables
174 */
175static double *sys_huffpuff; /* huff-n'-puff filter */
176static int sys_hufflen; /* huff-n'-puff filter stages */
177static int sys_huffptr; /* huff-n'-puff filter pointer */
178static double sys_mindly; /* huff-n'-puff filter min delay */
179
180#if defined(KERNEL_PLL)
181/* Emacs cc-mode goes nuts if we split the next line... */
182#define MOD_BITS (MOD_OFFSET | MOD_MAXERROR | MOD_ESTERROR | \
183 MOD_STATUS | MOD_TIMECONST)
184#ifdef SIGSYS
185static void pll_trap (int); /* configuration trap */
186static struct sigaction sigsys; /* current sigaction status */
187static struct sigaction newsigsys; /* new sigaction status */
188static sigjmp_buf env; /* environment var. for pll_trap() */
189#endif /* SIGSYS */
190#endif /* KERNEL_PLL */
191
192static void
193sync_status(const char *what, int ostatus, int nstatus)
194{
195 char obuf[256], nbuf[256], tbuf[1024];
196#if defined(USE_SNPRINTB) && defined (STA_FMT)
197 snprintb(obuf, sizeof(obuf), STA_FMT, ostatus);
198 snprintb(nbuf, sizeof(nbuf), STA_FMT, nstatus);
199#else
200 snprintf(obuf, sizeof(obuf), "%04x", ostatus);
201 snprintf(nbuf, sizeof(nbuf), "%04x", nstatus);
202#endif
203 snprintf(tbuf, sizeof(tbuf), "%s status: %s -> %s", what, obuf, nbuf);
204 report_event(EVNT_KERN, NULL, tbuf);
205}
206
207/*
208 * file_name - return pointer to non-relative portion of this C file pathname
209 */
210static char *file_name(void)
211{
212 if (this_file == NULL) {
213 (void)strncpy(relative_path, __FILE__, PATH_MAX);
214 for (this_file=relative_path;
215 *this_file && ! isalnum((unsigned char)*this_file);
216 this_file++) ;
217 }
218 return this_file;
219}
220
221/*
222 * init_loopfilter - initialize loop filter data
223 */
224void
225init_loopfilter(void)
226{
227 /*
228 * Initialize state variables.
229 */
230 sys_poll = ntp_minpoll;
231 clock_jitter = LOGTOD(sys_precision);
232 freq_cnt = (int)clock_minstep;
233}
234
235#ifdef KERNEL_PLL
236/*
237 * ntp_adjtime_error_handler - process errors from ntp_adjtime
238 */
239static void
240ntp_adjtime_error_handler(
241 const char *caller, /* name of calling function */
242 struct timex *ptimex, /* pointer to struct timex */
243 int ret, /* return value from ntp_adjtime */
244 int saved_errno, /* value of errno when ntp_adjtime returned */
245 int pps_call, /* ntp_adjtime call was PPS-related */
246 int tai_call, /* ntp_adjtime call was TAI-related */
247 int line /* line number of ntp_adjtime call */
248 )
249{
250 char des[1024] = ""; /* Decoded Error Status */
251
252 switch (ret) {
253 case -1:
254 switch (saved_errno) {
255 case EFAULT:
256 msyslog(LOG_ERR, "%s: %s line %d: invalid struct timex pointer: 0x%lx",
257 caller, file_name(), line,
258 (long)((void *)ptimex)
259 );
260 break;
261 case EINVAL:
262 msyslog(LOG_ERR, "%s: %s line %d: invalid struct timex \"constant\" element value: %ld",
263 caller, file_name(), line,
264 (long)(ptimex->constant)
265 );
266 break;
267 case EPERM:
268 if (tai_call) {
269 errno = saved_errno;
270 msyslog(LOG_ERR,
271 "%s: ntp_adjtime(TAI) failed: %m",
272 caller);
273 }
274 errno = saved_errno;
275 msyslog(LOG_ERR, "%s: %s line %d: ntp_adjtime: %m",
276 caller, file_name(), line
277 );
278 break;
279 default:
280 msyslog(LOG_NOTICE, "%s: %s line %d: unhandled errno value %d after failed ntp_adjtime call",
281 caller, file_name(), line,
282 saved_errno
283 );
284 break;
285 }
286 break;
287#ifdef TIME_OK
288 case TIME_OK: /* 0: synchronized, no leap second warning */
289 /* msyslog(LOG_INFO, "kernel reports time is synchronized normally"); */
290 break;
291#else
292# warning TIME_OK is not defined
293#endif
294#ifdef TIME_INS
295 case TIME_INS: /* 1: positive leap second warning */
296 msyslog(LOG_INFO, "kernel reports leap second insertion scheduled");
297 break;
298#else
299# warning TIME_INS is not defined
300#endif
301#ifdef TIME_DEL
302 case TIME_DEL: /* 2: negative leap second warning */
303 msyslog(LOG_INFO, "kernel reports leap second deletion scheduled");
304 break;
305#else
306# warning TIME_DEL is not defined
307#endif
308#ifdef TIME_OOP
309 case TIME_OOP: /* 3: leap second in progress */
310 msyslog(LOG_INFO, "kernel reports leap second in progress");
311 break;
312#else
313# warning TIME_OOP is not defined
314#endif
315#ifdef TIME_WAIT
316 case TIME_WAIT: /* 4: leap second has occured */
317 msyslog(LOG_INFO, "kernel reports leap second has occurred");
318 break;
319#else
320# warning TIME_WAIT is not defined
321#endif
322#ifdef TIME_ERROR
323#if 0
324
325from the reference implementation of ntp_gettime():
326
327 // Hardware or software error
328 if ((time_status & (STA_UNSYNC | STA_CLOCKERR))
329
330 /*
331 * PPS signal lost when either time or frequency synchronization
332 * requested
333 */
334 || (time_status & (STA_PPSFREQ | STA_PPSTIME)
335 && !(time_status & STA_PPSSIGNAL))
336
337 /*
338 * PPS jitter exceeded when time synchronization requested
339 */
340 || (time_status & STA_PPSTIME &&
341 time_status & STA_PPSJITTER)
342
343 /*
344 * PPS wander exceeded or calibration error when frequency
345 * synchronization requested
346 */
347 || (time_status & STA_PPSFREQ &&
348 time_status & (STA_PPSWANDER | STA_PPSERROR)))
349 return (TIME_ERROR);
350
351or, from ntp_adjtime():
352
353 if ( (time_status & (STA_UNSYNC | STA_CLOCKERR))
354 || (time_status & (STA_PPSFREQ | STA_PPSTIME)
355 && !(time_status & STA_PPSSIGNAL))
356 || (time_status & STA_PPSTIME
357 && time_status & STA_PPSJITTER)
358 || (time_status & STA_PPSFREQ
359 && time_status & (STA_PPSWANDER | STA_PPSERROR))
360 )
361 return (TIME_ERROR);
362#endif
363
364 case TIME_ERROR: /* 5: unsynchronized, or loss of synchronization */
365 /* error (see status word) */
366
367 if (ptimex->status & STA_UNSYNC)
368 snprintf(des, sizeof(des), "%s%sClock Unsynchronized",
369 des, (*des) ? "; " : "");
370
371 if (ptimex->status & STA_CLOCKERR)
372 snprintf(des, sizeof(des), "%s%sClock Error",
373 des, (*des) ? "; " : "");
374
375 if (!(ptimex->status & STA_PPSSIGNAL)
376 && ptimex->status & STA_PPSFREQ)
377 snprintf(des, sizeof(des), "%s%sPPS Frequency Sync wanted but no PPS",
378 des, (*des) ? "; " : "");
379
380 if (!(ptimex->status & STA_PPSSIGNAL)
381 && ptimex->status & STA_PPSTIME)
382 snprintf(des, sizeof(des), "%s%sPPS Time Sync wanted but no PPS signal",
383 des, (*des) ? "; " : "");
384
385 if ( ptimex->status & STA_PPSTIME
386 && ptimex->status & STA_PPSJITTER)
387 snprintf(des, sizeof(des), "%s%sPPS Time Sync wanted but PPS Jitter exceeded",
388 des, (*des) ? "; " : "");
389
390 if ( ptimex->status & STA_PPSFREQ
391 && ptimex->status & STA_PPSWANDER)
392 snprintf(des, sizeof(des), "%s%sPPS Frequency Sync wanted but PPS Wander exceeded",
393 des, (*des) ? "; " : "");
394
395 if ( ptimex->status & STA_PPSFREQ
396 && ptimex->status & STA_PPSERROR)
397 snprintf(des, sizeof(des), "%s%sPPS Frequency Sync wanted but Calibration error detected",
398 des, (*des) ? "; " : "");
399
400 if (pps_call && !(ptimex->status & STA_PPSSIGNAL))
401 report_event(EVNT_KERN, NULL,
402 "no PPS signal");
403 DPRINTF(1, ("kernel loop status %#x (%s)\n",
404 ptimex->status, des));
405 /*
406 * This code may be returned when ntp_adjtime() has just
407 * been called for the first time, quite a while after
408 * startup, when ntpd just starts to discipline the kernel
409 * time. In this case the occurrence of this message
410 * can be pretty confusing.
411 *
412 * HMS: How about a message when we begin kernel processing:
413 * Determining kernel clock state...
414 * so an initial TIME_ERROR message is less confising,
415 * or skipping the first message (ugh),
416 * or ???
417 * msyslog(LOG_INFO, "kernel reports time synchronization lost");
418 */
419 msyslog(LOG_INFO, "kernel reports TIME_ERROR: %#x: %s",
420 ptimex->status, des);
421 break;
422#else
423# warning TIME_ERROR is not defined
424#endif
425 default:
426 msyslog(LOG_NOTICE, "%s: %s line %d: unhandled return value %d from ntp_adjtime() in %s at line %d",
427 caller, file_name(), line,
428 ret,
429 __func__, __LINE__
430 );
431 break;
432 }
433 return;
434}
435#endif
436
437/*
438 * local_clock - the NTP logical clock loop filter.
439 *
440 * Return codes:
441 * -1 update ignored: exceeds panic threshold
442 * 0 update ignored: popcorn or exceeds step threshold
443 * 1 clock was slewed
444 * 2 clock was stepped
445 *
446 * LOCKCLOCK: The only thing this routine does is set the
447 * sys_rootdisp variable equal to the peer dispersion.
448 */
449int
450local_clock(
451 struct peer *peer, /* synch source peer structure */
452 double fp_offset /* clock offset (s) */
453 )
454{
455 int rval; /* return code */
456 int osys_poll; /* old system poll */
457 int ntp_adj_ret; /* returned by ntp_adjtime */
458 double mu; /* interval since last update */
459 double clock_frequency; /* clock frequency */
460 double dtemp, etemp; /* double temps */
461 char tbuf[80]; /* report buffer */
462
463 (void)ntp_adj_ret; /* not always used below... */
464 /*
465 * If the loop is opened or the NIST LOCKCLOCK is in use,
466 * monitor and record the offsets anyway in order to determine
467 * the open-loop response and then go home.
468 */
469#ifndef LOCKCLOCK
470 if (!ntp_enable)
471#endif /* not LOCKCLOCK */
472 {
473 record_loop_stats(fp_offset, drift_comp, clock_jitter,
474 clock_stability, sys_poll);
475 return (0);
476 }
477
478#ifndef LOCKCLOCK
479 /*
480 * If the clock is way off, panic is declared. The clock_panic
481 * defaults to 1000 s; if set to zero, the panic will never
482 * occur. The allow_panic defaults to FALSE, so the first panic
483 * will exit. It can be set TRUE by a command line option, in
484 * which case the clock will be set anyway and time marches on.
485 * But, allow_panic will be set FALSE when the update is less
486 * than the step threshold; so, subsequent panics will exit.
487 */
488 if (fabs(fp_offset) > clock_panic && clock_panic > 0 &&
489 !allow_panic) {
490 snprintf(tbuf, sizeof(tbuf),
491 "%+.0f s; set clock manually within %.0f s.",
492 fp_offset, clock_panic);
493 report_event(EVNT_SYSFAULT, NULL, tbuf);
494 return (-1);
495 }
496
497 allow_panic = FALSE;
498
499 /*
500 * This section simulates ntpdate. If the offset exceeds the
501 * step threshold (128 ms), step the clock to that time and
502 * exit. Otherwise, slew the clock to that time and exit. Note
503 * that the slew will persist and eventually complete beyond the
504 * life of this program. Note that while ntpdate is active, the
505 * terminal does not detach, so the termination message prints
506 * directly to the terminal.
507 */
508 if (mode_ntpdate) {
509 if ( ( fp_offset > clock_max_fwd && clock_max_fwd > 0)
510 || (-fp_offset > clock_max_back && clock_max_back > 0)) {
511 step_systime(fp_offset);
512 msyslog(LOG_NOTICE, "ntpd: time set %+.6f s",
513 fp_offset);
514 printf("ntpd: time set %+.6fs\n", fp_offset);
515 } else {
516 adj_systime(fp_offset);
517 msyslog(LOG_NOTICE, "ntpd: time slew %+.6f s",
518 fp_offset);
519 printf("ntpd: time slew %+.6fs\n", fp_offset);
520 }
521 record_loop_stats(fp_offset, drift_comp, clock_jitter,
522 clock_stability, sys_poll);
523 exit (0);
524 }
525
526 /*
527 * The huff-n'-puff filter finds the lowest delay in the recent
528 * interval. This is used to correct the offset by one-half the
529 * difference between the sample delay and minimum delay. This
530 * is most effective if the delays are highly assymetric and
531 * clockhopping is avoided and the clock frequency wander is
532 * relatively small.
533 */
534 if (sys_huffpuff != NULL) {
535 if (peer->delay < sys_huffpuff[sys_huffptr])
536 sys_huffpuff[sys_huffptr] = peer->delay;
537 if (peer->delay < sys_mindly)
538 sys_mindly = peer->delay;
539 if (fp_offset > 0)
540 dtemp = -(peer->delay - sys_mindly) / 2;
541 else
542 dtemp = (peer->delay - sys_mindly) / 2;
543 fp_offset += dtemp;
544 DPRINTF(1, ("local_clock: size %d mindly %.6f huffpuff %.6f\n",
545 sys_hufflen, sys_mindly, dtemp));
546 }
547
548 /*
549 * Clock state machine transition function which defines how the
550 * system reacts to large phase and frequency excursion. There
551 * are two main regimes: when the offset exceeds the step
552 * threshold (128 ms) and when it does not. Under certain
553 * conditions updates are suspended until the stepout theshold
554 * (900 s) is exceeded. See the documentation on how these
555 * thresholds interact with commands and command line options.
556 *
557 * Note the kernel is disabled if step is disabled or greater
558 * than 0.5 s or in ntpdate mode.
559 */
560 osys_poll = sys_poll;
561 if (sys_poll < peer->minpoll)
562 sys_poll = peer->minpoll;
563 if (sys_poll > peer->maxpoll)
564 sys_poll = peer->maxpoll;
565 mu = current_time - clock_epoch;
566 clock_frequency = drift_comp;
567 rval = 1;
568 if ( ( fp_offset > clock_max_fwd && clock_max_fwd > 0)
569 || (-fp_offset > clock_max_back && clock_max_back > 0)
570 || force_step_once ) {
571 if (force_step_once) {
572 force_step_once = FALSE; /* we want this only once after startup */
573 msyslog(LOG_NOTICE, "Doing intital time step" );
574 }
575
576 switch (state) {
577
578 /*
579 * In SYNC state we ignore the first outlier and switch
580 * to SPIK state.
581 */
582 case EVNT_SYNC:
583 snprintf(tbuf, sizeof(tbuf), "%+.6f s",
584 fp_offset);
585 report_event(EVNT_SPIK, NULL, tbuf);
586 state = EVNT_SPIK;
587 return (0);
588
589 /*
590 * In FREQ state we ignore outliers and inlyers. At the
591 * first outlier after the stepout threshold, compute
592 * the apparent frequency correction and step the phase.
593 */
594 case EVNT_FREQ:
595 if (mu < clock_minstep)
596 return (0);
597
598 clock_frequency = direct_freq(fp_offset);
599
600 /* fall through to EVNT_SPIK */
601
602 /*
603 * In SPIK state we ignore succeeding outliers until
604 * either an inlyer is found or the stepout threshold is
605 * exceeded.
606 */
607 case EVNT_SPIK:
608 if (mu < clock_minstep)
609 return (0);
610
611 /* fall through to default */
612
613 /*
614 * We get here by default in NSET and FSET states and
615 * from above in FREQ or SPIK states.
616 *
617 * In NSET state an initial frequency correction is not
618 * available, usually because the frequency file has not
619 * yet been written. Since the time is outside the step
620 * threshold, the clock is stepped. The frequency will
621 * be set directly following the stepout interval.
622 *
623 * In FSET state the initial frequency has been set from
624 * the frequency file. Since the time is outside the
625 * step threshold, the clock is stepped immediately,
626 * rather than after the stepout interval. Guys get
627 * nervous if it takes 15 minutes to set the clock for
628 * the first time.
629 *
630 * In FREQ and SPIK states the stepout threshold has
631 * expired and the phase is still above the step
632 * threshold. Note that a single spike greater than the
633 * step threshold is always suppressed, even with a
634 * long time constant.
635 */
636 default:
637 snprintf(tbuf, sizeof(tbuf), "%+.6f s",
638 fp_offset);
639 report_event(EVNT_CLOCKRESET, NULL, tbuf);
640 step_systime(fp_offset);
641 reinit_timer();
642 tc_counter = 0;
643 clock_jitter = LOGTOD(sys_precision);
644 rval = 2;
645 if (state == EVNT_NSET) {
646 rstclock(EVNT_FREQ, 0);
647 return (rval);
648 }
649 break;
650 }
651 rstclock(EVNT_SYNC, 0);
652 } else {
653 /*
654 * The offset is less than the step threshold. Calculate
655 * the jitter as the exponentially weighted offset
656 * differences.
657 */
658 etemp = SQUARE(clock_jitter);
659 dtemp = SQUARE(max(fabs(fp_offset - last_offset),
660 LOGTOD(sys_precision)));
661 clock_jitter = SQRT(etemp + (dtemp - etemp) /
662 CLOCK_AVG);
663 switch (state) {
664
665 /*
666 * In NSET state this is the first update received and
667 * the frequency has not been initialized. Adjust the
668 * phase, but do not adjust the frequency until after
669 * the stepout threshold.
670 */
671 case EVNT_NSET:
672 adj_systime(fp_offset);
673 rstclock(EVNT_FREQ, fp_offset);
674 break;
675
676 /*
677 * In FREQ state ignore updates until the stepout
678 * threshold. After that, compute the new frequency, but
679 * do not adjust the frequency until the holdoff counter
680 * decrements to zero.
681 */
682 case EVNT_FREQ:
683 if (mu < clock_minstep)
684 return (0);
685
686 clock_frequency = direct_freq(fp_offset);
687 /* fall through */
688
689 /*
690 * We get here by default in FSET, SPIK and SYNC states.
691 * Here compute the frequency update due to PLL and FLL
692 * contributions. Note, we avoid frequency discipline at
693 * startup until the initial transient has subsided.
694 */
695 default:
696 if (freq_cnt == 0) {
697
698 /*
699 * The FLL and PLL frequency gain constants
700 * depend on the time constant and Allan
701 * intercept. The PLL is always used, but
702 * becomes ineffective above the Allan intercept
703 * where the FLL becomes effective.
704 */
705 if (sys_poll >= allan_xpt)
706 clock_frequency +=
707 (fp_offset - clock_offset)
708 / ( max(ULOGTOD(sys_poll), mu)
709 * CLOCK_FLL);
710
711 /*
712 * The PLL frequency gain (numerator) depends on
713 * the minimum of the update interval and Allan
714 * intercept. This reduces the PLL gain when the
715 * FLL becomes effective.
716 */
717 etemp = min(ULOGTOD(allan_xpt), mu);
718 dtemp = 4 * CLOCK_PLL * ULOGTOD(sys_poll);
719 clock_frequency +=
720 fp_offset * etemp / (dtemp * dtemp);
721 }
722 rstclock(EVNT_SYNC, fp_offset);
723 if (fabs(fp_offset) < CLOCK_FLOOR)
724 freq_cnt = 0;
725 break;
726 }
727 }
728
729#ifdef KERNEL_PLL
730 /*
731 * This code segment works when clock adjustments are made using
732 * precision time kernel support and the ntp_adjtime() system
733 * call. This support is available in Solaris 2.6 and later,
734 * Digital Unix 4.0 and later, FreeBSD, Linux and specially
735 * modified kernels for HP-UX 9 and Ultrix 4. In the case of the
736 * DECstation 5000/240 and Alpha AXP, additional kernel
737 * modifications provide a true microsecond clock and nanosecond
738 * clock, respectively.
739 *
740 * Important note: The kernel discipline is used only if the
741 * step threshold is less than 0.5 s, as anything higher can
742 * lead to overflow problems. This might occur if some misguided
743 * lad set the step threshold to something ridiculous.
744 */
745 if (pll_control && kern_enable && freq_cnt == 0) {
746
747 /*
748 * We initialize the structure for the ntp_adjtime()
749 * system call. We have to convert everything to
750 * microseconds or nanoseconds first. Do not update the
751 * system variables if the ext_enable flag is set. In
752 * this case, the external clock driver will update the
753 * variables, which will be read later by the local
754 * clock driver. Afterwards, remember the time and
755 * frequency offsets for jitter and stability values and
756 * to update the frequency file.
757 */
758 ZERO(ntv);
759 if (ext_enable) {
760 ntv.modes = MOD_STATUS;
761 } else {
762#ifdef STA_NANO
763 ntv.modes = MOD_BITS | MOD_NANO;
764#else /* STA_NANO */
765 ntv.modes = MOD_BITS;
766#endif /* STA_NANO */
767 if (clock_offset < 0)
768 dtemp = -.5;
769 else
770 dtemp = .5;
771#ifdef STA_NANO
772 ntv.offset = (int32)(clock_offset * 1e9 +
773 dtemp);
774 ntv.constant = sys_poll;
775#else /* STA_NANO */
776 ntv.offset = (int32)(clock_offset * 1e6 +
777 dtemp);
778 ntv.constant = sys_poll - 4;
779#endif /* STA_NANO */
780 if (ntv.constant < 0)
781 ntv.constant = 0;
782
783 ntv.esterror = (u_int32)(clock_jitter * 1e6);
784 ntv.maxerror = (u_int32)((sys_rootdelay / 2 +
785 sys_rootdisp) * 1e6);
786 ntv.status = STA_PLL;
787
788 /*
789 * Enable/disable the PPS if requested.
790 */
791 if (hardpps_enable) {
792 ntv.status |= (STA_PPSTIME | STA_PPSFREQ);
793 if (!(pll_status & STA_PPSTIME))
794 sync_status("PPS enabled",
795 pll_status,
796 ntv.status);
797 } else {
798 ntv.status &= ~(STA_PPSTIME | STA_PPSFREQ);
799 if (pll_status & STA_PPSTIME)
800 sync_status("PPS disabled",
801 pll_status,
802 ntv.status);
803 }
804 if (sys_leap == LEAP_ADDSECOND)
805 ntv.status |= STA_INS;
806 else if (sys_leap == LEAP_DELSECOND)
807 ntv.status |= STA_DEL;
808 }
809
810 /*
811 * Pass the stuff to the kernel. If it squeals, turn off
812 * the pps. In any case, fetch the kernel offset,
813 * frequency and jitter.
814 */
815 ntp_adj_ret = ntp_adjtime(&ntv);
816 /*
817 * A squeal is a return status < 0, or a state change.
818 */
819 if ((0 > ntp_adj_ret) || (ntp_adj_ret != kernel_status)) {
820 kernel_status = ntp_adj_ret;
821 ntp_adjtime_error_handler(__func__, &ntv, ntp_adj_ret, errno, hardpps_enable, 0, __LINE__ - 1);
822 }
823 pll_status = ntv.status;
824#ifdef STA_NANO
825 clock_offset = ntv.offset / 1e9;
826#else /* STA_NANO */
827 clock_offset = ntv.offset / 1e6;
828#endif /* STA_NANO */
829 clock_frequency = FREQTOD(ntv.freq);
830
831 /*
832 * If the kernel PPS is lit, monitor its performance.
833 */
834 if (ntv.status & STA_PPSTIME) {
835#ifdef STA_NANO
836 clock_jitter = ntv.jitter / 1e9;
837#else /* STA_NANO */
838 clock_jitter = ntv.jitter / 1e6;
839#endif /* STA_NANO */
840 }
841
842#if defined(STA_NANO) && NTP_API == 4
843 /*
844 * If the TAI changes, update the kernel TAI.
845 */
846 if (loop_tai != sys_tai) {
847 loop_tai = sys_tai;
848 ntv.modes = MOD_TAI;
849 ntv.constant = sys_tai;
850 if ((ntp_adj_ret = ntp_adjtime(&ntv)) != 0) {
851 ntp_adjtime_error_handler(__func__, &ntv, ntp_adj_ret, errno, 0, 1, __LINE__ - 1);
852 }
853 }
854#endif /* STA_NANO */
855 }
856#endif /* KERNEL_PLL */
857
858 /*
859 * Clamp the frequency within the tolerance range and calculate
860 * the frequency difference since the last update.
861 */
862 if (fabs(clock_frequency) > NTP_MAXFREQ)
863 msyslog(LOG_NOTICE,
864 "frequency error %.0f PPM exceeds tolerance %.0f PPM",
865 clock_frequency * 1e6, NTP_MAXFREQ * 1e6);
866 dtemp = SQUARE(clock_frequency - drift_comp);
867 if (clock_frequency > NTP_MAXFREQ)
868 drift_comp = NTP_MAXFREQ;
869 else if (clock_frequency < -NTP_MAXFREQ)
870 drift_comp = -NTP_MAXFREQ;
871 else
872 drift_comp = clock_frequency;
873
874 /*
875 * Calculate the wander as the exponentially weighted RMS
876 * frequency differences. Record the change for the frequency
877 * file update.
878 */
879 etemp = SQUARE(clock_stability);
880 clock_stability = SQRT(etemp + (dtemp - etemp) / CLOCK_AVG);
881
882 /*
883 * Here we adjust the time constant by comparing the current
884 * offset with the clock jitter. If the offset is less than the
885 * clock jitter times a constant, then the averaging interval is
886 * increased, otherwise it is decreased. A bit of hysteresis
887 * helps calm the dance. Works best using burst mode. Don't
888 * fiddle with the poll during the startup clamp period.
889 */
890 if (freq_cnt > 0) {
891 tc_counter = 0;
892 } else if (fabs(clock_offset) < CLOCK_PGATE * clock_jitter) {
893 tc_counter += sys_poll;
894 if (tc_counter > CLOCK_LIMIT) {
895 tc_counter = CLOCK_LIMIT;
896 if (sys_poll < peer->maxpoll) {
897 tc_counter = 0;
898 sys_poll++;
899 }
900 }
901 } else {
902 tc_counter -= sys_poll << 1;
903 if (tc_counter < -CLOCK_LIMIT) {
904 tc_counter = -CLOCK_LIMIT;
905 if (sys_poll > peer->minpoll) {
906 tc_counter = 0;
907 sys_poll--;
908 }
909 }
910 }
911
912 /*
913 * If the time constant has changed, update the poll variables.
914 */
915 if (osys_poll != sys_poll)
916 poll_update(peer, sys_poll);
917
918 /*
919 * Yibbidy, yibbbidy, yibbidy; that'h all folks.
920 */
921 record_loop_stats(clock_offset, drift_comp, clock_jitter,
922 clock_stability, sys_poll);
923 DPRINTF(1, ("local_clock: offset %.9f jit %.9f freq %.3f stab %.3f poll %d\n",
924 clock_offset, clock_jitter, drift_comp * 1e6,
925 clock_stability * 1e6, sys_poll));
926 return (rval);
927#endif /* not LOCKCLOCK */
928}
929
930
931/*
932 * adj_host_clock - Called once every second to update the local clock.
933 *
934 * LOCKCLOCK: The only thing this routine does is increment the
935 * sys_rootdisp variable.
936 */
937void
938adj_host_clock(
939 void
940 )
941{
942 double offset_adj;
943 double freq_adj;
944
945 /*
946 * Update the dispersion since the last update. In contrast to
947 * NTPv3, NTPv4 does not declare unsynchronized after one day,
948 * since the dispersion check serves this function. Also,
949 * since the poll interval can exceed one day, the old test
950 * would be counterproductive. During the startup clamp period, the
951 * time constant is clamped at 2.
952 */
953 sys_rootdisp += clock_phi;
954#ifndef LOCKCLOCK
955 if (!ntp_enable || mode_ntpdate)
956 return;
957 /*
958 * Determine the phase adjustment. The gain factor (denominator)
959 * increases with poll interval, so is dominated by the FLL
960 * above the Allan intercept. Note the reduced time constant at
961 * startup.
962 */
963 if (state != EVNT_SYNC) {
964 offset_adj = 0.;
965 } else if (freq_cnt > 0) {
966 offset_adj = clock_offset / (CLOCK_PLL * ULOGTOD(1));
967 freq_cnt--;
968#ifdef KERNEL_PLL
969 } else if (pll_control && kern_enable) {
970 offset_adj = 0.;
971#endif /* KERNEL_PLL */
972 } else {
973 offset_adj = clock_offset / (CLOCK_PLL * ULOGTOD(sys_poll));
974 }
975
976 /*
977 * If the kernel discipline is enabled the frequency correction
978 * drift_comp has already been engaged via ntp_adjtime() in
979 * set_freq(). Otherwise it is a component of the adj_systime()
980 * offset.
981 */
982#ifdef KERNEL_PLL
983 if (pll_control && kern_enable)
984 freq_adj = 0.;
985 else
986#endif /* KERNEL_PLL */
987 freq_adj = drift_comp;
988
989 /* Bound absolute value of total adjustment to NTP_MAXFREQ. */
990 if (offset_adj + freq_adj > NTP_MAXFREQ)
991 offset_adj = NTP_MAXFREQ - freq_adj;
992 else if (offset_adj + freq_adj < -NTP_MAXFREQ)
993 offset_adj = -NTP_MAXFREQ - freq_adj;
994
995 clock_offset -= offset_adj;
996 /*
997 * Windows port adj_systime() must be called each second,
998 * even if the argument is zero, to ease emulation of
999 * adjtime() using Windows' slew API which controls the rate
1000 * but does not automatically stop slewing when an offset
1001 * has decayed to zero.
1002 */
1003 DEBUG_INSIST(enable_panic_check == TRUE);
1004 enable_panic_check = FALSE;
1005 adj_systime(offset_adj + freq_adj);
1006 enable_panic_check = TRUE;
1007#endif /* LOCKCLOCK */
1008}
1009
1010
1011/*
1012 * Clock state machine. Enter new state and set state variables.
1013 */
1014static void
1015rstclock(
1016 int trans, /* new state */
1017 double offset /* new offset */
1018 )
1019{
1020 DPRINTF(2, ("rstclock: mu %lu state %d poll %d count %d\n",
1021 current_time - clock_epoch, trans, sys_poll,
1022 tc_counter));
1023 if (trans != state && trans != EVNT_FSET)
1024 report_event(trans, NULL, NULL);
1025 state = trans;
1026 last_offset = clock_offset = offset;
1027 clock_epoch = current_time;
1028}
1029
1030
1031/*
1032 * calc_freq - calculate frequency directly
1033 *
1034 * This is very carefully done. When the offset is first computed at the
1035 * first update, a residual frequency component results. Subsequently,
1036 * updates are suppresed until the end of the measurement interval while
1037 * the offset is amortized. At the end of the interval the frequency is
1038 * calculated from the current offset, residual offset, length of the
1039 * interval and residual frequency component. At the same time the
1040 * frequenchy file is armed for update at the next hourly stats.
1041 */
1042static double
1043direct_freq(
1044 double fp_offset
1045 )
1046{
1047 set_freq(fp_offset / (current_time - clock_epoch));
1048
1049 return drift_comp;
1050}
1051
1052
1053/*
1054 * set_freq - set clock frequency correction
1055 *
1056 * Used to step the frequency correction at startup, possibly again once
1057 * the frequency is measured (that is, transitioning from EVNT_NSET to
1058 * EVNT_FSET), and finally to switch between daemon and kernel loop
1059 * discipline at runtime.
1060 *
1061 * When the kernel loop discipline is available but the daemon loop is
1062 * in use, the kernel frequency correction is disabled (set to 0) to
1063 * ensure drift_comp is applied by only one of the loops.
1064 */
1065static void
1066set_freq(
1067 double freq /* frequency update */
1068 )
1069{
1070 const char * loop_desc;
1071 int ntp_adj_ret;
1072
1073 (void)ntp_adj_ret; /* not always used below... */
1074 drift_comp = freq;
1075 loop_desc = "ntpd";
1076#ifdef KERNEL_PLL
1077 if (pll_control) {
1078 ZERO(ntv);
1079 ntv.modes = MOD_FREQUENCY;
1080 if (kern_enable) {
1081 loop_desc = "kernel";
1082 ntv.freq = DTOFREQ(drift_comp);
1083 }
1084 if ((ntp_adj_ret = ntp_adjtime(&ntv)) != 0) {
1085 ntp_adjtime_error_handler(__func__, &ntv, ntp_adj_ret, errno, 0, 0, __LINE__ - 1);
1086 }
1087 }
1088#endif /* KERNEL_PLL */
1089 mprintf_event(EVNT_FSET, NULL, "%s %.3f PPM", loop_desc,
1090 drift_comp * 1e6);
1091}
1092
1093
1094#ifdef KERNEL_PLL
1095static void
1096start_kern_loop(void)
1097{
1098 static int atexit_done;
1099 int ntp_adj_ret;
1100
1101 pll_control = TRUE;
1102 ZERO(ntv);
1103 ntv.modes = MOD_BITS;
1104 ntv.status = STA_PLL | STA_UNSYNC;
1105 ntv.maxerror = MAXDISPERSE * 1.0e6;
1106 ntv.esterror = MAXDISPERSE * 1.0e6;
1107 ntv.constant = sys_poll;
1108 /* ^^^^^^^^ why is it that here constant is
1109 * unconditionally set to sys_poll, whereas elsewhere is is
1110 * modified depending on nanosecond vs. microsecond kernel?
1111 */
1112#ifdef SIGSYS
1113 /*
1114 * Use sigsetjmp() to save state and then call ntp_adjtime(); if
1115 * it fails, then pll_trap() will set pll_control FALSE before
1116 * returning control using siglogjmp().
1117 */
1118 newsigsys.sa_handler = pll_trap;
1119 newsigsys.sa_flags = 0;
1120 if (sigaction(SIGSYS, &newsigsys, &sigsys)) {
1121 msyslog(LOG_ERR, "sigaction() trap SIGSYS: %m");
1122 pll_control = FALSE;
1123 } else {
1124 if (sigsetjmp(env, 1) == 0) {
1125 if ((ntp_adj_ret = ntp_adjtime(&ntv)) != 0) {
1126 ntp_adjtime_error_handler(__func__, &ntv, ntp_adj_ret, errno, 0, 0, __LINE__ - 1);
1127 }
1128 }
1129 if (sigaction(SIGSYS, &sigsys, NULL)) {
1130 msyslog(LOG_ERR,
1131 "sigaction() restore SIGSYS: %m");
1132 pll_control = FALSE;
1133 }
1134 }
1135#else /* SIGSYS */
1136 if ((ntp_adj_ret = ntp_adjtime(&ntv)) != 0) {
1137 ntp_adjtime_error_handler(__func__, &ntv, ntp_adj_ret, errno, 0, 0, __LINE__ - 1);
1138 }
1139#endif /* SIGSYS */
1140
1141 /*
1142 * Save the result status and light up an external clock
1143 * if available.
1144 */
1145 pll_status = ntv.status;
1146 if (pll_control) {
1147 if (!atexit_done) {
1148 atexit_done = TRUE;
1149 atexit(&stop_kern_loop);
1150 }
1151#ifdef STA_NANO
1152 if (pll_status & STA_CLK)
1153 ext_enable = TRUE;
1154#endif /* STA_NANO */
1155 report_event(EVNT_KERN, NULL,
1156 "kernel time sync enabled");
1157 }
1158}
1159#endif /* KERNEL_PLL */
1160
1161
1162#ifdef KERNEL_PLL
1163static void
1164stop_kern_loop(void)
1165{
1166 if (pll_control && kern_enable)
1167 report_event(EVNT_KERN, NULL,
1168 "kernel time sync disabled");
1169}
1170#endif /* KERNEL_PLL */
1171
1172
1173/*
1174 * select_loop() - choose kernel or daemon loop discipline.
1175 */
1176void
1177select_loop(
1178 int use_kern_loop
1179 )
1180{
1181 if (kern_enable == use_kern_loop)
1182 return;
1183#ifdef KERNEL_PLL
1184 if (pll_control && !use_kern_loop)
1185 stop_kern_loop();
1186#endif
1187 kern_enable = use_kern_loop;
1188#ifdef KERNEL_PLL
1189 if (pll_control && use_kern_loop)
1190 start_kern_loop();
1191#endif
1192 /*
1193 * If this loop selection change occurs after initial startup,
1194 * call set_freq() to switch the frequency compensation to or
1195 * from the kernel loop.
1196 */
1197#ifdef KERNEL_PLL
1198 if (pll_control && loop_started)
1199 set_freq(drift_comp);
1200#endif
1201}
1202
1203
1204/*
1205 * huff-n'-puff filter
1206 */
1207void
1208huffpuff(void)
1209{
1210 int i;
1211
1212 if (sys_huffpuff == NULL)
1213 return;
1214
1215 sys_huffptr = (sys_huffptr + 1) % sys_hufflen;
1216 sys_huffpuff[sys_huffptr] = 1e9;
1217 sys_mindly = 1e9;
1218 for (i = 0; i < sys_hufflen; i++) {
1219 if (sys_huffpuff[i] < sys_mindly)
1220 sys_mindly = sys_huffpuff[i];
1221 }
1222}
1223
1224
1225/*
1226 * loop_config - configure the loop filter
1227 *
1228 * LOCKCLOCK: The LOOP_DRIFTINIT and LOOP_DRIFTCOMP cases are no-ops.
1229 */
1230void
1231loop_config(
1232 int item,
1233 double freq
1234 )
1235{
1236 int i;
1237 double ftemp;
1238
1239 DPRINTF(2, ("loop_config: item %d freq %f\n", item, freq));
1240 switch (item) {
1241
1242 /*
1243 * We first assume the kernel supports the ntp_adjtime()
1244 * syscall. If that syscall works, initialize the kernel time
1245 * variables. Otherwise, continue leaving no harm behind.
1246 */
1247 case LOOP_DRIFTINIT:
1248#ifndef LOCKCLOCK
1249#ifdef KERNEL_PLL
1250 if (mode_ntpdate)
1251 break;
1252
1253 start_kern_loop();
1254#endif /* KERNEL_PLL */
1255
1256 /*
1257 * Initialize frequency if given; otherwise, begin frequency
1258 * calibration phase.
1259 */
1260 ftemp = init_drift_comp / 1e6;
1261 if (ftemp > NTP_MAXFREQ)
1262 ftemp = NTP_MAXFREQ;
1263 else if (ftemp < -NTP_MAXFREQ)
1264 ftemp = -NTP_MAXFREQ;
1265 set_freq(ftemp);
1266 if (freq_set)
1267 rstclock(EVNT_FSET, 0);
1268 else
1269 rstclock(EVNT_NSET, 0);
1270 loop_started = TRUE;
1271#endif /* LOCKCLOCK */
1272 break;
1273
1274 case LOOP_KERN_CLEAR:
1275#if 0 /* XXX: needs more review, and how can we get here? */
1276#ifndef LOCKCLOCK
1277# ifdef KERNEL_PLL
1278 if (pll_control && kern_enable) {
1279 memset((char *)&ntv, 0, sizeof(ntv));
1280 ntv.modes = MOD_STATUS;
1281 ntv.status = STA_UNSYNC;
1282 ntp_adjtime(&ntv);
1283 sync_status("kernel time sync disabled",
1284 pll_status,
1285 ntv.status);
1286 }
1287# endif /* KERNEL_PLL */
1288#endif /* LOCKCLOCK */
1289#endif
1290 break;
1291
1292 /*
1293 * Tinker command variables for Ulrich Windl. Very dangerous.
1294 */
1295 case LOOP_ALLAN: /* Allan intercept (log2) (allan) */
1296 allan_xpt = (u_char)freq;
1297 break;
1298
1299 case LOOP_CODEC: /* audio codec frequency (codec) */
1300 clock_codec = freq / 1e6;
1301 break;
1302
1303 case LOOP_PHI: /* dispersion threshold (dispersion) */
1304 clock_phi = freq / 1e6;
1305 break;
1306
1307 case LOOP_FREQ: /* initial frequency (freq) */
1308 init_drift_comp = freq;
1309 freq_set++;
1310 break;
1311
1312 case LOOP_HUFFPUFF: /* huff-n'-puff length (huffpuff) */
1313 if (freq < HUFFPUFF)
1314 freq = HUFFPUFF;
1315 sys_hufflen = (int)(freq / HUFFPUFF);
1316 sys_huffpuff = eallocarray(sys_hufflen, sizeof(sys_huffpuff[0]));
1317 for (i = 0; i < sys_hufflen; i++)
1318 sys_huffpuff[i] = 1e9;
1319 sys_mindly = 1e9;
1320 break;
1321
1322 case LOOP_PANIC: /* panic threshold (panic) */
1323 clock_panic = freq;
1324 break;
1325
1326 case LOOP_MAX: /* step threshold (step) */
1327 clock_max_fwd = clock_max_back = freq;
1328 if (freq == 0 || freq > 0.5)
1329 select_loop(FALSE);
1330 break;
1331
1332 case LOOP_MAX_BACK: /* step threshold (step) */
1333 clock_max_back = freq;
1334 /*
1335 * Leave using the kernel discipline code unless both
1336 * limits are massive. This assumes the reason to stop
1337 * using it is that it's pointless, not that it goes wrong.
1338 */
1339 if ( (clock_max_back == 0 || clock_max_back > 0.5)
1340 || (clock_max_fwd == 0 || clock_max_fwd > 0.5))
1341 select_loop(FALSE);
1342 break;
1343
1344 case LOOP_MAX_FWD: /* step threshold (step) */
1345 clock_max_fwd = freq;
1346 if ( (clock_max_back == 0 || clock_max_back > 0.5)
1347 || (clock_max_fwd == 0 || clock_max_fwd > 0.5))
1348 select_loop(FALSE);
1349 break;
1350
1351 case LOOP_MINSTEP: /* stepout threshold (stepout) */
1352 if (freq < CLOCK_MINSTEP)
1353 clock_minstep = CLOCK_MINSTEP;
1354 else
1355 clock_minstep = freq;
1356 break;
1357
1358 case LOOP_TICK: /* tick increment (tick) */
1359 set_sys_tick_precision(freq);
1360 break;
1361
1362 case LOOP_LEAP: /* not used, fall through */
1363 default:
1364 msyslog(LOG_NOTICE,
1365 "loop_config: unsupported option %d", item);
1366 }
1367}
1368
1369
1370#if defined(KERNEL_PLL) && defined(SIGSYS)
1371/*
1372 * _trap - trap processor for undefined syscalls
1373 *
1374 * This nugget is called by the kernel when the SYS_ntp_adjtime()
1375 * syscall bombs because the silly thing has not been implemented in
1376 * the kernel. In this case the phase-lock loop is emulated by
1377 * the stock adjtime() syscall and a lot of indelicate abuse.
1378 */
1379static RETSIGTYPE
1380pll_trap(
1381 int arg
1382 )
1383{
1384 pll_control = FALSE;
1385 siglongjmp(env, 1);
1386}
1387#endif /* KERNEL_PLL && SIGSYS */
